content:
I think in the meantime Table View is the only option. Cards View is still under development, and new features will be added over the coming year, e.g. the latest 120beta has a third row where additional info could be displayed.

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1860631
creator: sfhowes

content: Staying with Table View is the obvious solution. I think Card View is a development path towards a smartphone version of Thunderbird. That's why it is a simpler view.

creator: xgipper

content:
xgipper said
I find it very dispiriting that my question has only apparently had 1 view, and certainly no constructive comments. Many others have no answers too.

This is a peer support forum. We are also Thunderbird users. not developers and have no more access to the source code than you do. I have in the past seen all sorts of weird substitution issues occurring as reported in this forum over the years. Usually related to antivirus issues in the system temp folder, or outright corruption of that folders contents. Have you undertaken any action to clear the folder (windows does an appalling job of it. You would think it would have become better since widows V3 in 1985. Not not really. Manual intervention is still required frequently to clear house) Have you checked the integrity of the disk and the sanity of it's data structures (chkdsk) Sure you are seeing issues after an update. But there is nothing indicating they are linked and I would expect lots of others in this forum with the same issue if it was a defect in the released software.

There is other weird and annoying behaviour following this upgrade that I don't feel I needed, that I can't be bothered to document, which has me starting to wonder about moving apps.

And they may all be linked to a common issue. However unless you mention what is occurring no one else can tease out the links.

content:
For many imap accounts if email was put into the default imap TRash folder, the server empties the Trash periodically by default. This may not be the same for the server you are using.

Right click on imap Trash folder and select 'compact' Also do the same for he Inbox folder.

content:
What are your settings? They recommend:

incoming POP: pop3.mail.dk, 995, SSL/TLS, normal password, User Name = email address

incoming IMAP: imap.mail.dk, 993, SSL/TLS, normal password, User Name = email address

outgoing SMTP: asmtp.mail.dk, 587, STARTTLS, normal password, User Name = email address

If you have those and it doesn't work, state your antivirus (if it's not Windows/MS Security) and VPN if applicable.

content:
OK - thanks for images.

It looks like you have 'View' > 'Folders' > 'Unified' selected.

That means the top 'Inbox' is a 'Unified Inbox' and it should contain all emails which are located in all Inboxes for all accounts. As you have two mail account - BT and Local Folders, that means both would be under 'Unified Inbox'

As you only have one BT account then you do not really need to use 'Unified' option. Please tell me if you really want to use 'Unified' folders.

So do this first and then we can see which folders are really in the wrong location. 'View' > 'Folders' and select 'All' Then 'View' > 'Folders' > and select the 'Unified' to uncheck that option.
creator: Toad-Hall

If I could crack the problem of how to move folders with their sub-folders to the main Local folder (you can see the tip of the folders contained therein at the top of the picture) I'd be home and dry, even if it would be a tedious buisness. I've tried closing the sub-folders but these are not then taken under the 'Move' command for the main folder. Nor will they move separately.

I've been using TBird since 2009 without any problems I can recall (apart from those caused by BT) so the present situation is rather baffling!

DAW
creator: daw.hush

content:
Do not move any folders from an Imap account into 'Local Folders' mail account.

To move any folder to be a top level folder in 'Local Folders' mail account. eg: you want to move 'ARC' from 'Local Folders' 'Trash' folder to be a top level folder in 'Local Folders' mail account. Left click and hold down on 'ARC' folder and drag it upwards until you are hovering over the account name 'Local Folders' - then release to drop into 'Local Folders'.

To move any folder to be a subfolder of another folder: If you have eg: 'BVW' as a sub folder of 'Car -General' but you want it as a subfolder to eg: Woodland Trust Left click and hold down on 'BVW' folder and drag it upwards until you are hovering over the folder called 'Woodland Trust' - then release to drop into 'Woodland Trust'.

Any folder you select to move will also move anything it contains which includes all of it's subfolders and emails contained therein.

content: Okay, before you give up, look carefully in c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles . There may be more than one, and one would be bigger, due to accounts. Click in each to check Mail folder (if POP accounts, or Imapmail for IMAP accounts. And look also in Mail\Local folders for any local folders you may have. And don't forget to see if there is an abook.sqlite file (addressbook). If You find a profile folder that appears to be the one, See if you can use the tools>import>import from another installation menu option. And if not, the addressbook and local folders might still be valid and could be copied into a new profile you create if it comes to that.

content:
It is possible to have multiple profiles, with each one having a set of accounts, e.g. gmail accounts, work accounts etc. The Profile Switcher add-on simplifies the management.

If you wanted to aggregate accounts to, e.g. show all gmail Inboxes in a common folder, a Saved Search is available from File/New. Unified Folders is a special case of saved search.

One simple way to apply some organization is to order the accounts in the Folder Pane by rearranging them by drag and drop in Account Settings. Less important accounts can be collapsed to a single line in the Folder Pane.
creator: sfhowes

That folder which is now grey and italised has been given a 'no-select' flag. It means that greyed folder can contain other folders which contain emails, but it cannot contain any emails itself.

creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If this is a gmail account:

  • please logon to gmail webmail account via a browser
  • select 'Settings'
  • select 'See all settings'
  • Select 'labels'

scroll down to the section which shows all the 'labels' you have created. Lets say you have a top level folder called 'Clients' which is greyed out and it contains a folder called 'Bob' which looks normal. Do you have something like this: [Gmail]/Clients > Bob then: both Clients and Bob will be normal (selectable) folders In imap like this: Clients > Bob

But if you have this: [Gmail]/Clients > [Clients]/Bob

Then in imap you will see this: Clients > [Clients] - this shows as italic font and greyed. > > Bob

Can you post an image which shows what you see in webmail for all those folders you created. Also post an image showing the fodler Pane, so I can see which folder is effected and compare to what you have in gmail webmail.

content:
Unfortunately, this problem pops up after a "fix" has "fixed" the problem. Scare quotes are accurately used. I have tried many fixes and have found yet another. I wanted to share this solution and will comment again if this has fixed it. Leaving notes here for documentation in case others run into this same issue.

On a page titled "FIX: Print Spooler Keeps Stopping On Windows 10" https://helpdeskgeek.com/windows-10/fix-print-spooler-keeps-stopping-on-windows-10/ They advise to do configuration changes to Print Spooler in Windows. Windows 11 is just a kneecapped Windows 10, so this would apply. Open services.msc Open Print Spooler Set startup to Automatic In the recovery tab, make all three settings to restart the service

For my attempt, I didn't delete the printer cache, and this seemed to work for a few minutes of testing. I will make a note to return within seven days to confirm if this fix lasts that long.

content:
I am sad to state that this problem is not resolved, but it looks like it is NOT a problem with Mozilla Thunderbird. My client is buying a new Windows 11 computer rather than going through a reinstall of their operating system.

Despite telling Windows to force the Print Spooler always to restart the service, it would still go down and cause Thunderbird not to see printers. Other oddities are happening (<Ctrl>-

often causes Thunderbird to stop with errors), so the OS is causing trouble. I would love to have an answer for anyone in the future looking at this, but Microsoft's help fails us.

content: Filters are still the same, so I encourage you to play around with them. Select Tools>message filters and you will see the same pane you saw in the past. Also, I encourage you to periodically do a backup of your profile. The simple way is to install the import/export addon and select tools>importexporttools NG>export profile>fullprofile. content:
The folder with sent messages in gmail is named Sent Mail, and that is the folder that should be subscribed in TB (right-click the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe...). Sent messages are automatically copied to Sent Mail, so 'Place a copy in' should be unchecked in Account Settings, Copies & Folders.

If you are subscribed to the correct folder, see if Repair Folder from the folder's Properties context menu restores the missing messages. Do the same for the Sasktel Sent folder.
